title: Sadio Mane and Roberto Firmino criticised for not stepping up in Mohamed Salah's absence
text:

Sadio Mane and Roberto Firmino were criticised for being "short of the mark" as Liverpool were held to a draw by Man Utd on Sunday.

The Reds were without one third of their front three, with Mohamed Salah ruled out by an ankle injury picked up in their previous clash with Leicester .

Divock Origi stepped in to replace the Egyptian in the starting XI, but Liverpool struggled to get their usual intricate forward play going.

And Liverpool legend Steve Nicol placed the blame solely at the feet of Mane and Firmino.

“Whenever Salah comes out for whatever reason and you’ve got [Divock] Origi coming in, the drop-off is very big," Nicol told ESPN .

(Image: PA)

“Sometimes you can get away with it if you have Firmino and Mane at their best.

“But Firmino and Mane were way short of the mark.

“We all talk about Firmino and how he ties everything together, but everything fell apart when the ball went near him.

“Look, not a good day, but they definitely missed Salah.”

(Image: Getty Images)

Liverpool were hopeful Salah would make a full recovery from the twisted ankle he sustained from a dangerous lunge by Leicester's Hamza Choudhury.

His omission forced Jurgen Klopp to push Mane onto the right of the front three, with Origi on the left.

Mane did have the ball in the net for the Reds, but handled the ball before scoring, causing the goal to subsequently be ruled out by VAR.

Origi was involved in a VAR decision of his own, when United broke away to score through Marcus Rashford despite a foul on the Belgian in the build-up.

(Image: Getty Images)

Adam Lallana came off the bench to rescue a point for the Reds, which ex-Arsenal defender Martin Keown feels showed Liverpool's title credentials, but warned they must take on the pressures of being league leaders.

"Liverpool need to learn to enjoy the situation they are in," Keown told the Mail . "Yes, every man and his dog may be prematurely putting a crown on your heads, but you have to embrace that.

"Relish the pedestal you’re being put on. Liverpool lacked that mentality yesterday. They did not turn up at Old Trafford looking like a team that had won their last 17 Premier League games. They didn’t swagger in there like champions in waiting."
description: The usual Liverpool front three were a man down on Sunday as Divock Origi replaced the Egyptian in the starting XI
